NUS, or the National University of Singapore, offers a range of programs and courses aimed at supporting the development of digital skills and knowledge. Some examples of curriculum in NUS programs related to data science and analytics include:

1. Data Science Fundamentals: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts and techniques of data science, including data preparation, statistical analysis, and machine learning. Students learn how to work with data using a range of tools and technologies, and how to interpret and communicate the insights they uncover.
2. Data Mining and Predictive Analytics: This course explores the methods and techniques used in data mining and predictive analytics, including decision trees, clustering, and regression analysis. Students learn how to apply these methods to real-world problems and how to use data to make informed decisions.
3. Data Visualization: This course provides an introduction to the principles and practices of data visualization, including the use of tools such as Tableau, D3.js, and ggplot. Students learn how to create effective visualizations that help to communicate insights and support decision making.
4. Machine Learning: This course provides an in-depth exploration of machine learning techniques and algorithms, including linear and logistic regression, decision trees, and neural networks. Students learn how to use these methods to build predictive models and how to interpret the results.
5. Big Data Analytics: This course explores the challenges and opportunities presented by big data, including the use of tools such as Hadoop, Spark, and NoSQL databases. Students learn how to work with large datasets, how to process and analyze data at scale, and how to extract insights from big data.

These are just a few examples of the types of programs and courses that NUS offers to support the development of digital skills and knowledge. By providing students with the tools, techniques, and knowledge they need to work effectively with data, NUS is helping to build a more digitally enabled and responsive society and to support the growth of the digital economy in Singapore.

This has helped to protect the privacy and security of citizens and has supported the growth of the digital economy.

These are just a few examples of the digital services and infrastructure that have been developed in Singapore in recent years. By investing in these initiatives, the government is working to build a more digitally enabled and responsive society and to support the growth of the digital economy.
